"SECTION 1. TERRITORIAL AND FREELY ASSOCIATED STATE INFRASTRUCTURE ASSISTANCE." "Amendment to Section 4(b) of Public Law 94-241 limits payments to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to amounts set forth in multi-year funding agreements, subject to specific requirements." The special representatives of the President of the United States and the Governor of the Northern Mariana Islands must adhere to the Agreement's requirements. Additional funds in each fiscal year can be used for capital projects in American Samoa in 1996 and in Guam, the Virgin Islands, and American Samoa from 1997 onwards. For fiscal year 1996, funds are allocated for capital infrastructure projects in American Samoa. From fiscal year 1997 onwards, the funds are designated for projects in Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Palau, Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands. Additionally, $3 million is allocated to the College of the Northern Marianas in 1997, with a provision for up to $3 million annually for immigration and labor issues. In fiscal year 1997 and onwards, up to $3 million annually may be allocated for addressing immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues in the Northern Mariana Islands. The projects will be outlined in a five-year infrastructure plan developed by the Secretary of the Interior in consultation with the island governments and submitted to Congress. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with island governments, develops a five-year plan for capital infrastructure needs. The plan includes prioritizing projects, considering master plans, Corps of Engineers' recommendations, maintenance set-asides, local cost-share requirements, and proposing an incremental set-aside of up to $2 million per year. The plan includes prioritizing projects, considering master plans, Corps of Engineers' recommendations, maintenance set-asides, local cost-share requirements, proposing an incremental set-aside of up to $2 million per year, and an emergency fund of $10 million for natural disasters. Additional contributions may be made for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll. The plan includes an emergency fund of $10 million for natural disasters. Additional contributions may be made for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll, not exceeding $32 million from any Federal source after January 1, 1995, subject to specific conditions. The United States will provide funds for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll, to be audited and accounted for. Federal agencies in the Republic of the Marshall Islands can make funds available through the Secretary of the Interior for this purpose. Ex gratia assistance may also be provided under certain conditions, but only after all necessary funds for resettlement at Rongelap have been provided. SEC. 2. FEDERAL MINIMUM WAGE. Effective thirty days after enactment, the minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act will apply to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, starting at $2.75 per hour and increasing annually. The minimum wage rate applicable to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be $3.05 per hour, increasing by thirty cents per hour annually until it reaches the wage rate set forth in the Fair Labor Standards Act. Once it reaches that level, the minimum wage rate will be aligned with the wage rate in the Act. The text chunk "SEC. 3. REPORT." is a concise summary of the section regarding reporting in the context provided. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with other relevant departments, must report to Congress by March 15 each fiscal year on funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities. The report includes immigration data from the Immigration and Naturalization Service, such as the number of non-US citizen contract workers in the CNMI. The report to Congress by the Secretary of the Interior includes data on non-US citizen contract workers in the CNMI, their treatment, foreign government interference, laws' effect on Federal interests, detention facilities adequacy, and the alien identification system's accuracy. The report to Congress by the Secretary of the Interior addresses Federal interests, detention facilities in the Northern Mariana Islands, the accuracy of the alien identification system, and the challenges faced by Federal agencies in enforcing laws in the Commonwealth unless funded by the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. IMMIGRATION COOPERATION. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the Immigration and Naturalization Service will work together to identify and potentially exclude or deport individuals posing security or law enforcement risks to the Commonwealth or the United States. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF LOCAL EMPLOYMENT IN THE MARIANAS. Section 8103(i) of title 46 of the United States Code is amended to allow aliens in the CNMI to work as unlicensed seamen on vessels within US waters. Aliens in the CNMI are allowed to work as unlicensed seamen on vessels within US waters. Amendments to the United States Code grant them permission to accept such employment. SEC. 6 clarifies ownership of submerged lands in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. Public Law 93-435 (88 Stat. 1210) is amended by including the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in various sections. References to enactment dates in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will now refer to the date of enactment of this section. The Secretary of the Interior must provide an annual report to Congress on the economic development, federal assistance, local finances, infrastructure, and financial management of various islands. Additionally, a technical correction is included in the amendment. Section 501 of Public Law 95-134 is amended to replace "the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands" with "the Republic of Palau, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia." This amendment was passed by the Senate on July 20, 1995.
